Award.AwardTitle: Profiles of Technical Workforce Programs and Students at Two-Year Colleges
Award.AbstractNarration:
To maintain and expand the nation’s skilled technical workforce, it is essential to understand how technician education programs at two-year institutions support students’ academic and career pathways. However, significant gaps exist in the data needed to build this understanding. To address this gap, this project will develop and test a centralized system to collect the needed data. It will also develop a state-of-the-art visualization system to display and explore this data. These resources are intended to: (a) support peer, regional, national, and impact analyses of engineering-oriented technician programs; (b) make data available to federal and state agencies and researchers focused on STEM workforce issues; and (c) create a national digital directory of engineering-oriented technician programs at two-year colleges. This effort builds on the American Society for Engineering’s Profiles of Engineering and Engineering Technology Colleges Survey, which focuses on programs at four-year institutions. In addition, it responds to the National Science Board’s call for filling such data gaps, described in its report: The Skilled Technical Workforce: Crafting America’s Science and Engineering Enterprise.

The goals of the project are to: (1) develop and test a survey instrument and administration process for standardizing and collecting information on engineering-oriented technician programs at two-year institutions; (2) augment primary data collection with existing data sources; (3) design a common taxonomy and directory describing the types of two-year engineering degrees and certificates offered nationally; and (4) create and maintain an interactive data visualization system to analyze engineering-oriented technician programs at two-year institutions for peer, regional, and national comparisons. The project will implement a centralized data gathering effort that includes survey design/administration, sampling, and item analyses for reliability and validity. Additional data acquisition activities include linking existing data files to other data repositories and to primary survey data, including development of the algorithms required to accomplish linking of these independent data sources. Data visualization activities include the use data analytics and other approaches to facilitate the understanding of large, complex data sets. A national Advisory Board will guide project activities and evaluate their impact. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Profiles of Engineering Technology at Community & Technical Colleges (Profiles CTC) project aimed to bridge the knowledge gap about engineering technology and technician education offered by community colleges in the U.S. by gathering, analyzing, and disseminating comprehensive data. 

The project was launched to fill the gaps in the data and knowledge about two-year engineering-related technician programs at two-year colleges. The project established a Data Advisory Board and developed the Profiles CTC, modeled after the successful Profiles of Engineering & Engineering Technology programs survey for four-year  programs at U.S. colleges and universities. This survey was pilot-tested to refine data collection methods, ensuring relevance and accuracy. The data collected offers valuable insights into the demographics, enrollment trends, faculty composition, and program characteristics of community college engineering technology and technician programs, thereby enhancing our understanding of these essential educational pathways. 

The broader impacts of this project are significant. By creating a comprehensive taxonomy and an interactive data visualization system, the project has provided community colleges, policymakers, and industry leaders with accessible, detailed information about engineering technology programs. This system allows for benchmarking, program improvement, and strategic planning, which can lead to better educational outcomes and workforce readiness. 

Summary of Outcomes 

  1. Data Advisory Board: 

  • Composition and Expertise: The Data Advisory Board was composed of six professionals with deep expertise and experience in community college engineering technology and technician education. This included community college faculty, institutional researchers and industry, providing a broad spectrum of insights. 

  • Role and Contributions: The board played a crucial role in guiding the project, offering feedback on survey content, terminology, and data collection methods. They helped ensure that the survey captured relevant and useful data, reflecting the needs and realities of community & technical colleges. 

  • Adaptations Due to COVID-19: The board provided valuable input on how to adapt the survey and data collection processes in response to the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Their guidance helped maintain the project's momentum despite these challenges. 

  1. Profiles CTC Survey: 

  • Development Process: The survey was developed through a collaborative process involving the Data Advisory Board, projects external evaluators, and several ATE-PI project leaders. It was modeled after the established ASEE’s Profiles 1.0 survey but tailored to the specific context of community colleges. 

  • Pilot Testing: Two waves of pilot testing were conducted to refine the survey instrument. Although the initial pilot faced low response rates, adjustments were made to improve the survey's clarity and relevance. 

  • Challenges and Solutions: The pandemic created significant hurdles in securing survey responses. Despite these challenges, the survey was successfully developed and distributed, providing a foundation for future data collection efforts. 

  1. Taxonomy Development: 

  • Creation and Purpose: A comprehensive taxonomy of community college engineering technology and technician degrees and certificates was developed. This taxonomy categorizes programs by region, state, type of program, and other relevant factors. 

  • Stakeholder Input: The taxonomy was created with input from the Data Advisory Board that included representations from key stakeholder communities and was based on analysis of IPEDS data. It provides a standardized framework for classifying and comparing programs across different institutions. 

  1. Interactive Data Visualization System: 

  • Design and Features: An interactive data visualization system was designed to provide easy access to the collected data. This system includes functionalities for generating graphs and tables, making it user-friendly for a wide range of stakeholders. 

  • Data Sources: The system incorporates data from IPEDS and the Profiles 2.0 survey, offering comprehensive insights into community college engineering technology programs. It allows users to explore data on program enrollments, completions, demographics, and more. 

  • User Feedback and Enhancements: Feedback from community college practitioners was gathered to improve the system. Enhancements were made to ensure the system is accessible, user-friendly, and meets the needs of various user groups. 

  1. Scaling the Impact: 

  • Directory Compilation: A directory of community & technical college engineering technology programs was compiled using IPEDS data. This directory includes detailed information on programs offered, degrees conferred, and institutional characteristics. 

  • Public Access: The directory and the data visualization system are publicly available, allowing broad access to this valuable information (https://americansocietyforengineeringeducation.shinyapps.io/profilesctc/ ). Stakeholders can use these tools for benchmarking, program improvement, and strategic planning. 

  • Research and Policy Applications: The collected data and developed tools are valuable resources for research and policy formulation. They enable stakeholders to analyze trends, identify gaps, and develop strategies to enhance the quality and impact of technical education. 

The Profiles CTC project successfully met its goals, despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. The data collected and the tools developed have provided a robust foundation for understanding and improving community college engineering technology and technician programs.

The project leaders believe that there is a compelling need for ongoing data collection undertaken under this project. It is hoped that a sustainable system will be established that can undertake this task.   


Last Modified: 07/26/2024
Modified by: Joseph Roy

The project was launched to fill the gaps in the data and knowledge about two-year engineering-related technician programs at two-year colleges. The project established a Data Advisory Board and developed the Profiles CTC, modeled after the successful Profiles of Engineering & Engineering Technology programs survey for four-year programs at U.S. colleges and universities. This survey was pilot-tested to refine data collection methods, ensuring relevance and accuracy. The data collected offers valuable insights into the demographics, enrollment trends, faculty composition, and program characteristics of community college engineering technology and technician programs, thereby enhancing our understanding of these essential educational pathways. The broader impacts of this project are significant. By creating a comprehensive taxonomy and an interactive data visualization system, the project has provided community colleges, policymakers, and industry leaders with accessible, detailed information about engineering technology programs. This system allows for benchmarking, program improvement, and strategic planning, which can lead to better educational outcomes and workforce readiness. Adaptations Due to COVID-19: The board provided valuable input on how to adapt the survey and data collection processes in response to the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Their guidance helped maintain the project's momentum despite these challenges. Pilot Testing: Two waves of pilot testing were conducted to refine the survey instrument. Although the initial pilot faced low response rates, adjustments were made to improve the survey's clarity and relevance. Challenges and Solutions: The pandemic created significant hurdles in securing survey responses. Despite these challenges, the survey was successfully developed and distributed, providing a foundation for future data collection efforts. Taxonomy Development: Creation and Purpose: A comprehensive taxonomy of community college engineering technology and technician degrees and certificates was developed. It provides a standardized framework for classifying and comparing programs across different institutions. Data Sources: The system incorporates data from IPEDS and the Profiles 2.0 survey, offering comprehensive insights into community college engineering technology programs. It allows users to explore data on program enrollments, completions, demographics, and more. User Feedback and Enhancements: Feedback from community college practitioners was gathered to improve the system. Enhancements were made to ensure the system is accessible, user-friendly, and meets the needs of various user groups. This directory includes detailed information on programs offered, degrees conferred, and institutional characteristics. They enable stakeholders to analyze trends, identify gaps, and develop strategies to enhance the quality and impact of technical education. The Profiles CTC project successfully met its goals, despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. The data collected and the tools developed have provided a robust foundation for understanding and improving community college engineering technology and technician programs. The project leaders believe that there is a compelling need for ongoing data collection undertaken under this project.
